I'm wondering if the people who claim Hurricane Irene is overhyped remember

1. 5.3 inches of rain fell over a 2 hour period of time and shut down the subways for half a day in August 2008.

2. New Orleans thought it had weathered Hurricane Katrina and the worst was over... but that was before the levees broke.

Better to prepare for the worst, than to be surprised by it.

Just went for a stroll, and there is a lot of water in the air, also it's somewhat gusty. If I didn't know better, I'd say we were having a summer rainstorm. A few other stubborn Newyawkers were walking around too, but it looked like all businesses were closed. Went down to the subway and it was bone dry, but I guess the elevated lines could have some problems. A couple of cops staying dry down there were surprised and irritated to see me, but I explained I was on a fact-finding mission and wished them a good night, and they cheerily waved and said 'take care'.

So far I am glad I prepared for this by stocking up, not because of the storm, but because of the preparations for it, which will be quite a hassle for the next couple of days. I will probably post again when the mood strikes me, so make sure to put duct tape on your monitor.

As a child I frequently traveled through unaccompanied minor programs on various airlines, after your millionith time in the program you are a more expenienced traveler than those families with the three kids going to Disney for the first time.... By 10 I was able to connect without an issue (I left my escort behind), and by 14 I was traveling internationally without help. It was expected of me that I know how to check myself in, and what to do in case of emergency. Children these days now have to added benefit of cell phones and if needed prepaid credit cards. It is absurd to think that a 15 year old (who in one year will be driving a car) can't make it through an airport by themself!

I also agree that $380 million is a little excessive. But before criticizing, do the math:

* Assuming inflation of 3%, this amounts to about $300 million in today's dollars.
* Assuming $300 million, this amounts to $30 million per year, which is HALF the bonus he got this year (about which most people are not complaining).
* This bonus is not guaranteed, and is only worth the current value if he keeps the company running smoothly for 5-10 years (which is beyond the 3-5 year horizon after which everyone is worried Apple will run out of ideas).

In the last calendar year alone, Apple made $14 billion in profits, and is worth ~$350 billion. Next year (fiscal 2012), it is expected to make $30 billion. So $30 million doesn't seem excessive in this case. The problem with executive compensation is less than amount (which does seem excessive) but lack of correlation with the company's success -- see Merrill Lynch, Citibank and others.

What a stupid post.

The precautions being taken are necessary because of the potential damage Irene could cause, particularly in terms of storm surge. Millions of people are potentially affected, with almost 2 million having lost power already. Widespread flooding has occurred - it's been raining for almost 13 hours straight in coastal NC - and several tornadoes have been reported in NC, DE, and Philadelphia. NYC is under a tornado watch. Sick and elderly people were transported elsewhere. A hospital in DE is in danger of losing power. Nine people have died so far.

Find something better to do than to mock the situation.
A lot of politicians -- governors and mayors -- learned from Katrina that it's a whole lot easier to apologise for overreacting than to explain later why they hadn't reacted.

You can never be too prepared for something like this. It's very impressive how municipalities, cities, and states have prepared as this monster hurricane-which apparently does not have high winds for a hurricane (C-I) but derives its high damage potential from the tidal surge factor-lurches slowly up the East Coast.
Let us have no more Katrinas. Everyone is on the same page-no political silliness or botched evacuations-,that's exactly what is needed to make it through an event like this safely in terms of lives and with a minimum amount of property damage considering the power of this storm.
Hats off to good planning (and clear instructions), people helping out on the job and as volunteers, and-lest we forget-citizens who follow directions!
